The first computer the author used for programming was the IBM 1401, which was used by his school district for data processing. He started using it in 9th grade, around the age of 13 or 14. The programming language he used was an early version of Fortran. The author faced several challenges while using this computer. The only form of input to programs was data stored on punched cards, and he didn't have any data stored on punched cards. The only other option was to do things that didn't rely on any input, like calculate approximations of pi, but he didn't know enough math to do anything interesting of that type. Therefore, he couldn't figure out what to do with it and in retrospect, he believes there's not much he could have done with it.
The two specific influences that led the author to develop an interest in AI were a novel and a documentary. The novel was "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress" by Heinlein, which featured an intelligent computer named Mike. The author was drawn into the world of the novel and felt it was only a matter of time before we'd have an intelligent computer like Mike. The documentary was a PBS documentary that showed Terry Winograd using SHRDLU, a computer program that used natural language processing. Seeing Winograd use SHRDLU made the author believe that the development of AI was imminent.
The two main influences that initially drew the author to AI were a novel by Heinlein called "The Moon is a Harsh Mistress," which featured an intelligent computer called Mike, and a PBS documentary that showed Terry Winograd using SHRDLU. The realization that led him to believe that the approach to AI during his time was a hoax was that the AI programs of the time, which translated natural language into formal representations and added them to their knowledge base, were not truly understanding natural language. He realized that there was an unbridgeable gap between what these programs could do and actual understanding of natural language.
The author shifted his interest towards Lisp after realizing that the way AI was practiced at the time, with explicit data structures representing concepts, was not going to work. He found that Lisp was interesting for its own sake and not just for its association with AI, which was the main reason people cared about it at the time. To further his understanding of Lisp, he decided to write a book about Lisp hacking. He mentions that writing a book about something can help you learn it. The book he wrote, "On Lisp," was mostly written during his time in grad school.
The author in the essay is Paul Graham, who was pursuing a PhD in computer science but also developed an interest in art. He found himself in a complex situation where he was simultaneously exploring different fields and trying to reconcile his interests.In terms of computer science, Graham was particularly interested in Lisp, a programming language. He decided to write a book about Lisp hacking, titled "On Lisp," as a way to deepen his understanding of the language. He was also intrigued by the idea of building things that would last, which he felt was a challenge in the field of systems work in computer science as any program written would eventually become obsolete.On the other hand, Graham also developed a fascination with art. He was inspired by a visit to the Carnegie Institute where he realized that paintings, unlike software, do not become obsolete and can last for hundreds of years. This realization led him to consider the possibility of becoming an artist himself. Despite having no prior experience, he started taking art classes at Harvard while still being in the PhD program.Graham found himself working on multiple projects that were not related to his thesis. He was writing his book on Lisp, taking art classes, and still trying to complete his PhD. He was in a dilemma about how to reconcile his varied interests and find a way out of grad school.A turning point came when his professor asked if he was ready to graduate. Despite not having written a word of his dissertation, Graham decided to write one in the remaining weeks before the deadline, reusing parts of his book "On Lisp" where he could. This decision reflects his attempt to reconcile his interests by integrating his work on Lisp into his academic obligations.
The author decided to write a book on Lisp hacking primarily because he found Lisp interesting in its own right, separate from its association with AI. He also believed that writing a book about something is a good way to learn it. This reflects his approach to learning and problem-solving as being hands-on and experiential. He's not afraid to dive into a subject he's not fully versed in, using the process of writing and explaining to deepen his understanding. This approach suggests a willingness to take risks and learn through doing, rather than relying solely on prior knowledge or expertise.
The author decided to attempt writing his dissertation in the 5 weeks that remained before the deadline, despite not having a single word written yet. He planned to execute this by reusing parts of his work from "On Lisp" where he could.
According to the author's account, the students and faculty at the Accademia di Belli Arti had an arrangement where the students wouldn't require the faculty to teach anything, and in return the faculty wouldn't require the students to learn anything. The author describes this as an adherence to the conventions of a 19th century atelier. The students spent their time chatting or occasionally trying to imitate things they'd seen in American art magazines. The author also mentions that hardly anyone else painted the model besides him. This suggests that the general approach to learning and teaching in this institution was rather informal and not very rigorous.
In the essay, the author explains that painting a still life is different from painting a person because the subject of a still life doesn't move, unlike a person who can't sit still for more than about 15 minutes. When painting people, the traditional method is to know how to paint a generic person, which is then modified to match the specific person being painted. In contrast, a still life can be copied pixel by pixel from what the artist is seeing.The author suggests that painting still lives allows for a deeper understanding of visual perception. In everyday life, much of what we see is processed by low-level brain functions that provide a general understanding of what we're seeing, without detailing every aspect. However, when painting a still life, the artist must look more closely and notice details that are usually overlooked. The author notes that this process of careful observation can lead to new discoveries even after days of painting something that people usually take for granted. Therefore, painting still lives can enhance visual perception by encouraging a more detailed and conscious observation of the world.
Interleaf, the company where the author worked, had added a unique feature to their software. Inspired by Emacs, they incorporated a scripting language into their software, which was even made as a dialect of Lisp. This bold move was significant as it allowed for more complex and flexible operations within the software.The author's role in the company was to write things in this scripting language, essentially functioning as a Lisp hacker. However, the author self-assesses his performance as poor. He admits to being a bad employee, stating that he didn't understand most of the software because their Lisp was just a thin layer on top of a large amount of C code, a language he didn't know and didn't want to learn. Additionally, he confesses to being terribly irresponsible, particularly in relation to the traditional working hours that were expected at the time.
The author was hired by Interleaf as a Lisp hacker to write scripts in their scripting language, which was a dialect of Lisp. However, the author admits to being a bad employee, as he didn't understand most of the software due to it being primarily written in C, a language he didn't know or want to learn. Additionally, he found the traditional expectations of a programming job, such as showing up every day during certain working hours, unnatural. He often spent his time working on his own project, On Lisp, during work hours. This differed from the traditional expectations of a programming job which typically required focused work on assigned tasks during specified working hours.
A "signature style" is a unique and identifiable aesthetic or approach that an artist applies to their work, making it immediately recognizable as their own. In the context of painting, it's the visual equivalent of what's known as a "schtick" in show business - something that immediately identifies the work as belonging to a specific artist. An example given by the author is Roy Lichtenstein, known for his paintings that resemble a certain kind of cartoon. When you see a painting of this type, you can immediately identify it as Lichtenstein's work.
The author initially perceived the World Wide Web as a significant and transformative development. He believed that the web would be a "big deal" and could have a similar impact on the internet as graphical user interfaces had on the popularity of microcomputers. This is evident from the text where he says, "It seemed to me that the web would be a big deal. I'd seen what graphical user interfaces had done for the popularity of microcomputers. It seemed like the web would do the same for the internet." The author also saw the web as a potential avenue for wealth creation, referring to it as "the next train leaving the station" in terms of financial opportunity.
The author's idea of starting a company to put art galleries online was not successful because, according to his experience, art galleries did not want to be online, especially the fancy ones. He suggests that this is not how they sell their art.
The initial idea for a startup by Paul Graham and Robert Morris was to put art galleries online. The idea failed because art galleries didn't want to be online, especially the fancy ones, as that's not how they sell. They wrote software to generate web sites for galleries and to resize images and set up an http server to serve the pages, but they struggled to sign up galleries. Even when they offered to make sites for free, they couldn't get galleries to pay for the service.
The pivotal moment in the essay when the author realized the potential of running software on the server and allowing users to control it through their browsers occurred when he was lying on a mattress in Robert's apartment in Cambridge. He had the idea that if they ran the software on the server and let users control it by clicking on links, they would never have to write anything to run on users' computers. They could generate the sites on the same server they'd serve them from, and users wouldn't need anything more than a browser.This realization had a significant impact on the development of their company, Viaweb. They decided to try making a version of their store builder that could be controlled through the browser. A few days later, they had a working prototype. Despite the user interface being horrible, it proved that they could build a whole store through the browser, without any client software or typing anything into the command line on the server. This led them to believe they were onto something big, envisioning a new generation of software working this way. This change in direction led to the creation of Viaweb, a company that worked via the web.
The three main parts of the software developed for the online store builder were the editor, the shopping cart, and the manager. The author, Paul Graham, was responsible for writing the editor, which people used to build sites. Robert wrote the shopping cart, which presumably handled the purchasing process for customers. Trevor was responsible for the manager, which kept track of orders and statistics.
The author and his team priced their ecommerce software at $100 a month for a small store and $300 a month for a big one. This low price was attractive to customers as it was affordable and provided value for money. It posed a problem for competitors because it was challenging for them to match or beat these prices while maintaining profitability. The author's personal financial situation influenced this pricing strategy because they were poor at the time. This caused them to perceive $300 a month as a lot of money, leading them to price their product lower than they might have if they had a better understanding of what businesses typically paid for such services. This lack of knowledge inadvertently led to a competitive pricing strategy.
The author's lack of business knowledge inadvertently contributed to the success of Viaweb in several ways. First, the author and his team set the price of their service low, charging $100 a month for a small store and $300 a month for a big one. This was not a strategic decision based on market research or business acumen, but rather because they were poor and $300 seemed like a lot of money to them. This low price turned out to be a big attraction for customers and a competitive advantage over other businesses.Second, the author's lack of understanding about scaling led them to do things that didn't scale, such as building stores for their users. While this seemed humiliating and counterintuitive at the time, it turned out to be beneficial as it helped them understand retail and how their software was used, and it also helped them acquire users.Lastly, the author's lack of business knowledge led them to focus on the absolute number of users rather than the growth rate. While this was a mistake in the author's eyes, it turned out that their growth rate was fine and they were growing 7x a year, which is a good sign for a startup.
The author believes that the growth rate is the ultimate test of a startup. He learned that the absolute number of users is important for immediate revenue, but in the long term, a high growth rate will ensure the absolute number increases. He reflects that if he had understood this earlier, he would have advised himself not to stress and not to hire too many people, as the company was growing seven times a year and was on the path to profitability.However, he did hire more people, influenced by investor expectations and the norms of startups during the Internet Bubble. This decision delayed the company's break-even point and left them dependent on investors. The author regrets this, describing the result as a mess. Despite the company being profitable and growing rapidly, the author felt the near-death experiences every few months due to financial stress.Eventually, Yahoo bought Viaweb, which the author describes as a huge relief and a transition from rags to riches. The author's perspective on the importance of growth rate, combined with his lack of understanding of how to value a business and manage growth, led to a stressful journey but ultimately a successful sale of the company.
In the essay, the author describes a significant shift in his lifestyle after selling his company to Yahoo. Initially, he lived a grad student lifestyle, which didn't change much even after starting his company. However, after the sale to Yahoo, he experienced a sudden transition from rags to riches. He bought a car, a yellow 1998 VW GTI, which he considered a luxury, and moved to California.However, the following year was the least productive of his life. He was worn out from the stress of running Viaweb and struggled to adapt to Yahoo's work culture. Despite the wealth he had acquired, he felt unfulfilled and decided to leave Yahoo in the summer of 1999 to pursue his passion for painting.Upon leaving Yahoo, he immediately started painting. However, he found that he lacked energy and ambition. He attributed part of this to his isolation in California, having bought a house in the Santa Cruz Mountains, far from any social connections. In desperation, he returned to New York, where he still had his old apartment.Back in New York, he resumed his old life, but now he was rich. This wealth opened up new opportunities for him. He no longer had to walk everywhere; he could hail a taxi. He could afford to eat at charming little restaurants. His painting started to improve, and he began experimenting with new techniques.However, despite the financial freedom, the author seemed to struggle with finding fulfillment and maintaining his ambition to paint. The transition from a grad student lifestyle to sudden wealth brought about new opportunities but also new challenges in his pursuit of his passion.
The author's new approach to still life painting involved creating an initial painting in the traditional manner, then photographing it and printing the image, enlarged, onto a canvas. This printed image served as the underpainting for a second still life, which was painted from the same objects as the first, provided they hadn't decayed. This innovative technique reflects the author's ability to adapt creatively to his new circumstances. Being wealthy, he could afford the resources to experiment with new methods. Furthermore, his return to New York, a city known for its vibrant art scene, might have inspired him to push the boundaries of his craft.
In the essay, the author discusses the idea of creating a web application for making web applications. This would allow people to edit code on the server through the browser, and then host the resulting applications for them. The author also envisioned running various services on the servers that these applications could use just by making an API call, such as making and receiving phone calls, manipulating images, taking credit card payments, etc. The author believed this was the future of web apps because it would streamline the process of creating and hosting web applications, and provide a platform for integrating various services.
The author mentions that Lisp hackers often dream of building a new Lisp partly because one of the distinctive features of the language is that it has dialects. Additionally, he suggests that Lisp hackers may have in their minds a Platonic form of Lisp that all existing dialects fall short of.
In Paul Graham's essay, his work on the new dialect of Lisp, Arc, is significant as it represents his contribution to the open-source community. He had spent a considerable amount of time thinking about this new architecture and even attempted to write some of it. This experience proved to be very useful when he encountered startups working on parts of this new architecture after starting Y Combinator.His work on Arc also reflects his perspective towards open source projects. He saw the potential of building a new Lisp, a dream shared by many Lisp hackers, due to its distinctive feature of having dialects and the idea of a Platonic form of Lisp that all existing dialects fall short of. This shows his belief in the continuous improvement and evolution of open source projects, and his willingness to contribute to this process.Furthermore, his work on Arc and the subsequent feedback he received from the community may have influenced his perspective on the power of the internet as a platform for sharing ideas and knowledge. This is evident when he started publishing essays online and realized the potential of the web as a medium for publishing, which was not limited by the traditional constraints of print media.
In the essay, Paul Graham describes a significant shift in publishing essays from the print era to the digital era. During the print era, the channel for publishing essays was very narrow, with only a few officially anointed thinkers and specialists in their fields allowed to publish. The digital era, however, opened up the possibility for anyone to publish anything, a concept that Graham admits took him several years to fully comprehend.Graham views this shift as a revolutionary change that allows for a whole new generation of essays. He acknowledges that it was surprising to realize that if he wrote something and put it on the web, anyone could read it. This realization led him to understand that there were so many essays that had never been written because there had been no way to publish them in the print era. Now, these essays could be written and published online.Despite recognizing that online essays would be viewed as a marginal medium at first, Graham found this encouraging rather than discouraging. He saw the lack of prestige in online essays as a sign of something real to be discovered and a test of the right kind of motives. He warns against the danger of impure motives, such as the desire to impress people, and suggests that working on things that aren't prestigious can help avoid the most common type of wrong path.In summary, Paul Graham views the shift from print to digital publishing as a liberating change that opens up new possibilities for essay writing. He sees it as an opportunity for new voices to be heard and new ideas to be shared, even if they initially lack prestige.
In Paul Graham's essay, several key events and individuals influenced his decision to start an investment firm. One of the key individuals was Jessica Livingston, a woman he met at a party at his house. Jessica worked in marketing at a Boston investment bank and was compiling a book of interviews with startup founders. When she had to look for a new job due to financial problems at her bank, Paul began sharing his ideas about what needed to change in venture capital. Jessica's experience and insights from the startup world and her job search played a significant role in shaping their decision to start an investment firm.Another key event was a talk Paul gave at the Harvard Computer Society on how to start a startup. During this talk, he shared his belief that the best sources of seed funding were successful startup founders. This talk made him realize that he should stop procrastinating about angel investing, a thought he had been entertaining since Yahoo bought his company.Paul also mentions his friends Robert and Trevor, with whom he had been scheming about potential projects. Their shared history and desire to collaborate again influenced his decision to start an investment firm, with the idea that they could all work together on this new venture.Finally, the frustration with the slow decision-making process of traditional venture capitalists (VCs) was a significant factor. This led to the decision to start their own investment firm, where they could implement their ideas and strategies. The lack of established angel investors to learn from in Boston in 2005 also played a role, as it forced them to make their own choices, some of which turned out to be novel.
Paul Graham found that giving talks was an effective strategy for writing essays. The pressure of having to present to a group of people and provide them with valuable information spurred his imagination and helped him generate ideas. This approach also influenced his perspective on starting a startup. When he was asked to give a talk to the Harvard Computer Society, he decided to discuss how to start a startup, hoping to help them avoid common mistakes. During this talk, he suggested that the best sources of seed funding were successful startup founders, as they could also provide advice. This led him to consider angel investing and eventually inspired the idea of starting his own investment firm.
Y Combinator, as described in Paul Graham's essay, took a unique approach towards investing in startups. Unlike traditional VC firms and angel investors, Y Combinator was not organized as a fund and was funded with their own money. This was different from VC firms which were organized companies making large investments, and angels who were individuals making smaller investments on the side. Y Combinator's plan was to make seed investments and also provide support to startups in ways that traditional investors didn't, such as helping them get set up as a company.Another distinctive feature of Y Combinator was its batch model. They would fund a group of startups all at once, twice a year, and then spend three months focusing intensively on trying to help them. This was discovered by accident due to their lack of experience as investors. They saw it as a way to gain experience by funding a bunch of startups at once, which was not a common practice among traditional investors.An example of this approach in action was the Summer Founders Program, where they invited undergrads to start startups instead of taking up temporary jobs at tech companies during the summer. This program resulted in a surprising number of applications, including from people who had already graduated or were about to. From these, they selected 8 groups to fund, including future successful companies like Reddit and Twitch. This shows how Y Combinator's unique approach allowed them to discover and invest in promising startups at an early stage.
In Paul Graham's essay, the inception of the Summer Founders Program (SFP) came about as a way for Graham and his partners to gain experience as investors. They decided to fund a bunch of startups all at once, twice a year, and spend three months focusing intensively on helping them. The idea was to organize a summer program where undergraduates would start startups instead of getting temporary jobs at tech companies. The building Graham owned in Cambridge was used as headquarters, and weekly dinners and talks by startup experts were organized.The SFP was announced on Graham's site, inviting undergraduates to apply. Surprisingly, they received 225 applications, many from people who had already graduated or were about to graduate. They invited about 20 of these groups for in-person interviews and selected 8 to fund.The first batch of the SFP included notable participants who made significant contributions to the tech industry. This included the founders of Reddit, Justin Kan and Emmett Shear who later founded Twitch, Aaron Swartz who helped write the RSS spec and became a martyr for open access, and Sam Altman who later became the second president of Y Combinator. Graham notes that the success of the first batch was not entirely due to luck, implying their selection and support process was effective.
The deal for startups in the Summer Founders Program was based on a combination of a previous deal with Julian ($10k for 10%) and what MIT grad students got for the summer ($6k). The program invested $6k per founder, which in the typical two-founder case was $12k, in return for 6%. It was determined to be fair because it was twice as good as the deal that the program organizers had taken themselves. Additionally, during the first summer, the founders were provided with free air conditioners.
Hacker News (HN) was initially created as a news aggregator for startup founders, but its focus shifted to cater to future startup founders, engaging their intellectual curiosity. It played a significant role in Y Combinator (YC) as it was beneficial for the organization. However, it was also a significant source of stress for the author. The author mentions that if his only task was to select and help founders, his life would have been much easier, implying that managing HN was a challenging task. He likens his situation to running a marathon with an ill-fitting shoe, causing more pain than the marathon itself. He states that when dealing with urgent problems during YC, there was a 60% chance it was related to HN, and a 40% chance it was related to everything else combined. Despite the stress, the author also wrote all of YC's internal software in Arc, the same language used to create HN. This indicates that HN was a significant part of the author's work in YC.
In the essay, Robert Morris advised Paul Graham to ensure that Y Combinator (YC) isn't the last cool thing he does. Initially, Paul did not understand the advice, but he later realized that Robert was suggesting he should quit YC. This advice significantly impacted Paul's decision about his role at YC. He acknowledged that if he continued on his current trajectory, YC would consume all his attention and become the last thing he did. This realization, along with personal circumstances, led him to decide to hand over YC to someone else.
The transition of leadership at Y Combinator was described as a thoughtful and gradual process. Initially, Jessica was asked if she wanted to be president, but she declined the offer. The team then decided to approach Sam Altman for the role. The decision to recruit Sam was part of a larger plan to ensure the longevity of Y Combinator. The founders believed that for YC to last a long time, it couldn't be controlled by the founders, hence the need for a change in leadership. Sam initially declined the offer as he wanted to start a startup to make nuclear reactors. However, after persistent efforts, Sam finally agreed to take over as president in October 2013. The transition was gradual, with Sam taking over more responsibilities towards the end of 2013. This was partly to allow him to learn the job and partly because the author was focused on his mother, whose cancer had returned.
The author decided to step away from YC to help get a batch of startups through Demo Day, and then he checked out completely. He was also dealing with the death of his mother, whose cancer had returned. He decided to start painting as he wanted to do something completely different and see how good he could get if he really focused on it. However, in November, while in the middle of a painting, he ran out of steam and found finishing the painting to be a chore, so he stopped painting. He then started writing essays again and in March 2015, he started working on Lisp. The author mentions that attention is a zero-sum game and if a project isn't the best one for you, it's getting in the way of another project that is. This could be a reason why he decided to return to writing essays and working on Lisp.
In the essay, the author describes Lisp as a programming language that originated as a model of computation, which gave it a power and elegance that other languages couldn't match. This unique origin is what initially attracted the author to Lisp during his college years.The author explains that Lisp was invented by John McCarthy in 1960, and its core is defined by writing an interpreter in itself. It wasn't originally intended to be a programming language in the ordinary sense, but rather a formal model of computation, an alternative to the Turing machine. The minimum set of predefined operators needed to write an interpreter for a language in itself is what defines the Lisp that McCarthy invented.However, McCarthy didn't realize this Lisp could be used to program computers until his grad student Steve Russell suggested it. Russell translated McCarthy's interpreter into IBM 704 machine language, and from that point, Lisp began to be used as a programming language in the ordinary sense.The author notes that McCarthy's original Lisp did nothing more than interpret Lisp expressions and was missing many features that are desirable in a programming language. These features had to be added later, but they weren't defined using McCarthy's original axiomatic approach because it wouldn't have been feasible at the time due to the limitations of computers.The author concludes by suggesting that with the power of modern computers, it would now be possible to continue using McCarthy's axiomatic approach to define a complete programming language. As long as every change made to McCarthy's Lisp was a discoveredness-preserving transformation, one could, in principle, end up with a complete language that retained the unique qualities of Lisp.
The author developed a new programming language called Bel. The unique approach used in its creation was continuing McCarthy's axiomatic approach until a complete programming language was defined. The author also wrote this new language, Bel, in itself in Arc, which involved a lot of trickery and hacks to make it work.
The significant life change that occurred during the development of the programming language was the author's move to England in the summer of 2016. The author and his family moved to England because they wanted their kids to experience living in another country. Originally, they intended to stay for a year, but they liked it so much that they decided to continue living there. This move impacted the author's work on the project as most of the programming language, Bel, was written in England.
In Paul Graham's essay, he reflects on his own decision-making process, demonstrating how personal experiences and introspection can greatly influence professional choices. He begins by asking himself how he had chosen what to work on in the past, indicating that he is drawing on his personal experiences to guide his future decisions. This introspective process leads him to a long and messy answer, suggesting that his decision-making process is complex and influenced by various factors from his life experiences.For example, he mentions that he wrote an essay for himself to answer the question of how he chooses what to work on. This indicates that he uses writing as a tool for introspection, allowing him to articulate and understand his thoughts and experiences better. This introspective process can lead to surprising insights, as it did for Graham when he found his answer to be longer and messier than expected.Furthermore, he thought that his introspective journey might be interesting and encouraging to others with similarly messy lives. This suggests that he believes his personal experiences and the insights gained from introspection can be valuable not only for his own decision-making process but also for others in similar situations.In the notes, Graham also shares various personal experiences, from his time living in Florence (note 3) to his experiences with software and online publishing (notes 9, 10, 11). These experiences likely influenced his professional decisions, demonstrating how personal experiences can shape our professional lives.In conclusion, Graham's essay illustrates how personal experiences and introspection can influence decision-making in professional life. By reflecting on past experiences and using introspection to understand our thoughts and feelings, we can gain valuable insights that guide our professional choices.
Without the full context of the essay, it's difficult to determine the exact significance of each note. However, we can make some assumptions based on the content of the notes themselves. For example, let's take note [10]: "This was the first instance of what is now a familiar experience, and so was what happened next, when I read the comments and found they were full of angry people. How could I claim that Lisp was better than other languages? Weren't they all Turing complete? People who see the responses to essays I write sometimes tell me how sorry they feel for me, but I'm not exaggerating when I reply that it has always been like this, since the very beginning. It comes with the territory. An essay must tell readers things they don't already know, and some people dislike being told such things."This note appears to discuss the author's experience with criticism and backlash, particularly in relation to his opinions on programming languages. It might contribute to the overall theme or message of the essay by highlighting the challenges and criticisms that come with sharing new or controversial ideas, a theme that could be relevant if the essay is about the author's experiences as a writer or a programmer. It could also be a reflection on the nature of online discourse and the resistance to new ideas or change.
Yes, Paul Graham discusses the concept of customs and their lasting influence in the essay. He uses the example of venture capital (VC) practices and the publishing of essays to illustrate this point. In the case of VC practices, he explains that these customs were formed during a time when startups were expensive to start and rare. However, even though startups can now be cheap and common, the customs of VCs still reflect the constraints of the old world. Similarly, he talks about how the customs of publishing essays still reflect the constraints of the print era, despite the advent of online publishing. He further argues that independent-minded individuals, who are less influenced by these outdated customs, have an advantage in fields affected by rapid change. This is because these customs are more likely to be obsolete in such rapidly changing environments.
Paul Graham uses the analogy of advanced alien civilizations to explain the concept of invented versus discovered knowledge. He suggests that certain fundamental concepts, like the Pythagorean theorem, would be known to any sufficiently advanced civilization, implying that these concepts are discovered, universal truths rather than human inventions. He also posits that these civilizations might know about Lisp, a programming language from McCarthy's 1960 paper, indicating that some technological advancements might also be universal discoveries. However, he also suggests that there's no reason to believe that this would be the limit of their knowledge. He speculates that these civilizations would likely have a need for numbers, errors, and I/O, and thus there could be other paths of discovery beyond what we currently know.
In the essay, Paul Graham uses the concept of an advanced alien civilization to illustrate the idea of invented versus discovered knowledge. He posits that any sufficiently advanced alien civilization would certainly know about the Pythagorean theorem, suggesting that this knowledge is universal and thus discovered, not invented. He also believes, though with less certainty, that these aliens would know about the Lisp in McCarthy's 1960 paper. This implies that the Lisp language, like the Pythagorean theorem, is a discovered knowledge that transcends human invention. He further speculates that there might be no limit to the language that might be known to these aliens, suggesting the possibility of more discovered knowledge.
Paul Graham describes his experience of leaving YC and no longer working with Jessica as like "pulling up a deeply rooted tree". This metaphor suggests that their professional relationship was deeply intertwined with their personal lives, and was not something that could be easily separated or removed. It reveals that their work on YC was a significant part of their relationship and that leaving it was a significant and potentially difficult change.
The main function of the "starred docs" feature in Coda docs is to mark documents of personal importance. After a document is starred, it can be found in a section on your document list called "My Shortcuts". This feature only affects the user's personal view and does not impact others in the workspace.
"Starring" a document only saves it to your personal "My Shortcuts" and doesn't affect the view for others in your workspace. On the other hand, "pinning" a document is used when you want to shortcut docs not just for yourself but also for others in your team or workspace.
To star a document in Braintrust, you can either hover over the document's name in the document list and click the star icon, or you can do it from within the document itself by hovering over the document title in the upper left corner and clicking on the star. Once a document is starred, it can be quickly accessed from the "My Shortcuts" tab of your document list. If you no longer need quick access to the document, you can un-star it by clicking the star again, which will remove it from the "My Shortcuts" tab.
When you click the star again after a document has already been starred in Braintrust, it un-stars the document and removes it from the "My Shortcuts" tab of your doc list.
The document describes a process where you can reference columns by typing "@" and then choosing the column you want to reference from a dropdown menu. You can also format these values by selecting the column chip and using the selection menu to bold, underline, italicize and more.

The file size (442) could refer to the number of bytes, kilobytes, or other units, but it doesn't directly translate to the number of words or pages in the document. Factors such as formatting, images, and non-text content can also affect the file size.
In Coda's formula language, the formula editor is activated by using the "=" sign. This feature allows users to perform more complex calculations. It can be particularly useful for performing functions on a column per row, such as determining if a Launch date is overdue. By default, any formulas entered will reference the current row, referred to as thisRow. If users want to reference other rows, tables, etc., they need to reference them by their full name.
The default reference used when entering formulas is the current row, referred to as "thisRow". If you want to reference other rows, tables, etc., you need to reference them by their full name.
Typing **/** (forward slash) in the Compose column brings up a list of elements such as headings, bullets, emojis, and more.
When you highlight existing text in the Compose column, it brings up the text formatting bar.
In the context of Compose columns, converting a formulaic column into an editable one involves a few steps. First, you need to right-click on the column header. This will bring up a menu from which you select "Column options". In the subsequent dialog, you should find and click the "Convert to editable" option, which is usually located towards the bottom.After this conversion, several changes occur in the column. The Compose tab, which was present before, is removed. The current values that were in the column are stored and these values become editable at the cell level. This means you can manually change the values in each cell. Furthermore, these values will no longer update based on any previously referenced column values or formulas. This gives you more control over the data in the column, as it is no longer strictly governed by the original instructions or formulas.
When you choose the "Convert to editable" option, the Compose tab is removed and the current values in the column are stored. This means that the values in the column are now editable in each cell and will no longer update based on any previously referenced column values or formulas.
A Canvas column allows you to put pages within the cells of a table. Each cell of a canvas column is directly editable, meaning you can manually modify the content of each cell without affecting any other cells in that column. For example, if you have a Canvas column in a table, you can individually edit the content of each cell, like adding text or images.On the other hand, a Compose column allows you to generate dynamic page content within the cells of a table. The content for each cell is predetermined "behind the scenes", meaning the contents for each cell are automatically calculated and created for each new row. Each cell of a Compose column is not manually editable. The contents of each cell are pre-determined based on the settings of the column. For example, if you have a Compose column, the content of each cell is auto-filled based on the predetermined settings, and you can't manually edit the content of each cell.
Compose columns primarily support text, dynamic text, and formatted text. Images can also be added either by copy/paste, or by referencing an image column. Other Coda objects like buttons, tables, reactions, etc., are not supported in Compose columns. The context does not provide specific reasons why these other objects are not supported.
The context information does not provide a specific definition or example of the term "thisRow" in Coda formulas. However, it suggests that there are related resources available that could provide more information on the topic.

Coda has recently added the ability to share a doc with specific Google Groups.
The three main points discussed in the article are how to invite specific Google Groups to your doc, how to access a doc that's been shared with your Google Group, and FAQs related to these topics.
To invite a specific Google Group to your doc, follow these steps:1. Click the **Share** button in the upper right corner of the doc. 2. In the text field, type the Google group email address that you’d like to share the doc with. 3. Click on the **Invite Google Group email button** to provide your OAuth credentials. 4. Decide what type of access the group should have and hit **Send**.Alternatively, you can connect with Google Groups by:1. Going to the **Members** page in your workspace, and navigating to the **Groups** tab. 2. Provide your OAuth credentials. 3. Go to any doc that you want to share and type the email address of the Google Group you'd like to share with. 4. Click on the **Invite Google Group email** button and hit send.If you’ve previously shared docs with Google Groups, you need to remove those email addresses and re-add them by clicking on the **Invite Google Group email** button.Note that you or at least one member in your workspace must connect with Google Groups by providing your OAuth credentials to enable sharing with Google Groups. Once you or a workspace member provides their OAuth credentials, everyone in the workspace will be able to share docs with Google Groups.
Providing OAuth credentials is significant in the process of sharing documents with Google Groups as it enables the connection between the workspace and Google Groups. Once a workspace member provides their OAuth credentials, everyone in the workspace will be able to share docs with Google Groups. This means that the ability to share documents with Google Groups is not limited to the individual who provided the OAuth credentials, but is extended to all members in the workspace.
OAuth credentials are used to verify a user's identity and group membership. When a user tries to access a document shared with a Google Group they are a member of, they need to provide their OAuth credentials. Coda uses these credentials to confirm their membership in the group and subsequently grant access to the document.
If a member of a Google Group is trying to open a shared document and encounters a specific screen, they should click on the **Check Groups access** button. After clicking this button, they will need to provide their OAuth credentials. These credentials are used by Coda to verify their group membership and subsequently grant access to the document. This process ensures that only verified members of the group can access the shared document.
No, documents cannot be shared with personal Google groups or nested groups in the context of Google Workspace. The document specifically mentions that sharing with Google groups is only available for Google Workspace users and does not support sharing with personal Google groups (i.e groups with a .googlegroups.com extension). It also does not support sharing with nested groups.
Group members will not receive email notifications if the organization does not allow "anyone on the web" to post to a Google group. In this case, group members would need a link to the document to access it.
The key difference between starring and pinning a document in the context of document management is that starring a document is for personal importance and only applies to your own view and your own shortcuts. On the other hand, pinning a document is recommended when you want to flag or shortcut a document for everyone in your workspace or folder.
No, you cannot star a document for everyone in your workspace. According to the text, starring docs is a personal action that only applies to your own view and your own My Shortcuts. If you want to flag or shortcut a document for everyone in your workspace, you should pin it instead.

Coda AI is a work assistant with a variety of features designed to generate or edit content in a Coda doc:1. **AI assistant:** This feature creates content on the page canvas of a Coda doc using instructions provided in a prompt box. The instructions can reference content within another page or table to generate new paragraphs, checklists, tables with data, and more. It can also edit existing text on the canvas.2. **AI column:** The AI column feature creates content within a table via a prompt that can reference other data within the row. This allows for dynamic content creation within tables.3. **AI block:** This feature generates an AI-powered block on the page of your doc. It can summarize or find action items from data in tables or other pages, providing a quick overview or actionable insights from your data.4. **AI chat:** The AI chat feature allows for brainstorming ideas, iterating on content, or getting answers across your doc. It’s always available to collaborate, located in your side panel.These features can be used to automate the creation and editing of content in a Coda doc, making it easier to manage and update documents.
Coda AI utilizes the @ reference function in its prompt instructions to generate or edit content. This function allows it to reference other pages, tables, or data within the same row as part of the instructions on what content to create. For instance, the prompt instructions can @ reference content within another page or table to generate new paragraphs, checklists, tables with data, and more. It can also edit existing text on the canvas. Additionally, within a table, a prompt that can @ reference other data within the row can be used to create content.
Sure, here are the steps to create a table using the Coda AI assistant:1. Type **/** (forward slash) or **Ctrl+Space** into the canvas of your document. 2. Under the AI options in the dropdown, select **Make a table...** 3. Write a prompt of your choice, but include instructions to create a table. Examples include:    * Generate a table with 10 potential target audiences    * Create a table with 15 questions and answers for a new hire    * Create a table with 20 potential names and a short press release for a new editor feature    * Make a table of pros & cons to consider when opening a new office 4. Once the table is generated, you’ll see a pop-up where you can provide further instructions to Coda AI, such as making the generated text shorter. You can also change the original prompt. 5. When you have the results you want, hit **Keep**.Tips provided in the document include: * You can @ reference other pages or tables in your document by typing **@** into the prompt bar, or clicking the **@ button**.  * You can also write **=** to open the formula builder.
The AI assistant feature can generate different types of content such as text, tables, and edited text.1. **Text**: This can include formatted headers, checklists, bullet points, paragraphs, and more. To generate text, you need to type a forward slash ( / ) or Ctrl+Space into a new line in your document. Then, under the AI options in the dropdown, select "Write a...", and write a prompt of your choice. Examples of prompts include "What are 10 activities our team can do at an offsite?" or "Write a blog about brand loyalty". Once the content is generated, you can provide further instructions to the AI, such as making the generated text shorter. When satisfied, press "Keep" to finalize.2. **Tables**: AI can create tables with populated data. To create a table, type a forward slash ( / ) or Ctrl+Space into the canvas of your document. Then, under the AI options in the dropdown, select "Make a table...", and write a prompt of your choice that includes instructions to create a table. Examples include "Generate a table with 10 potential target audiences" or "Create a table with 20 potential names and a short press release for a new editor feature". Once the table is generated, you can provide further instructions to the AI, such as making the generated text shorter. When you have the results you want, hit "Keep".3. **Edited Text**: The AI can also edit existing text. To do this, highlight the text you want to edit on the canvas or in a canvas column. In the inline toolbar popup, select the AI option, and provide instructions in the prompt. Select "Create", and if needed, you can provide further instructions to the AI, such as making the generated text shorter. When you have the results you want, hit "Keep".
To use the AI column to generate content for multiple cells in a table, follow these steps:1. Click on the **Add column** button, which is located in the upper right corner of the table. This will add a blank column to your table.2. Decide if you want the AI to create content in one, multiple, or all cells in the column. If you want to fill multiple cells, you should highlight the cells you want to fill.3. After highlighting the desired cells, select the **Fill** button at the bottom of the table.4. A prompt box will open. Here, you should write a prompt with instructions for the AI. You can choose one of the options provided, or write your own instructions. In the prompt, you can @ reference other data within the same row, or type = to open the formula builder.5. After writing the prompt, you can select your desired length, tone and type for the content that the AI will generate.6. Finally, click on **Fill** to have the AI generate and insert the content into the selected cells. Please note that the document also mentions a gif titled "Ai column walkthru.gif" which likely provides a visual walkthrough of this process.
The document doesn't provide specific examples of how to use the @ reference or the formula builder in the prompt. However, it mentions that in the prompt, you can use @ to reference other data within the same row. This likely means that you can use @ followed by the column name or identifier to pull data from that column into the prompt. For example, if you have a column named "Name" and you want to generate a greeting for each name in a new column, your prompt might be "Write a greeting for @Name."The document also mentions you can type = to open the formula builder. While it doesn't provide specific details about how this works, it suggests that you can use formulas to manipulate or calculate data for your prompt. For example, if you have columns for "Price" and "Quantity", you might use a formula like "=Price*Quantity" to calculate the total cost in a new column.Remember, these are just inferred examples based on the general information given in "section_23.md". The actual usage might vary depending on the specific software or tool you're using.
To generate a summary using the AI block in the document, follow these steps:1. Type **/** (forward slash) or **Ctrl+Space** into the canvas of your doc. 2. From the AI dropdown options, select **Summarize**. 3. In your prompt, @ reference the table or the page that contains your notes or relevant information. You can also type **=** to open the formula builder. 4. Choose your desired length, tone and type. 5. Select **Create**.The key components you need to specify before selecting "Create" are the source of the information (table or page), the desired length of the summary, the tone, and the type.
To use the AI block to find action items from a table or a page in your notes, you should first type **/** (forward slash) or **Ctrl+Space** into the canvas of your doc. From the AI dropdown options, select **Find action items from...**. In your prompt, @ reference the table or the page that contains your notes. You can also type **=** to open the formula builder. Choose your desired length, tone and type. It is recommended to use checkboxes for the type of action items. After setting these parameters, select **Create**. To keep this information updated, hover over the block and click the rounded arrow in the upper right corner whenever you need to update the action items block.
To use AI chat, follow these steps:1. Open the AI icon, which is located in the bottom right next to the ? icon. 2. Select one of the prompts or write your own. Some examples of prompts include:    - Where can I find more information about what this team is working on?    - What are the key milestones and dates?    - What are the pros and cons with the suggested plan?    - Write 5 suggestions of titles for this page.    - Write a closing paragraph for this blog.    - Create a table with next steps and action items. 3. Choose the context you want to provide: no context, the current page, or the current doc. You can also highlight text on the current page, and choose that selection as the context. 4. After Coda AI generates a response, you can add it to the current page (or open up a new one), by pressing insert. 5. You can also provide more instructions, and AI chat will generate more content. 6. When you’re done, close AI chat, and open it back up again whenever you want.
In the document "section_25.md", context plays a significant role in using AI chat. The context refers to the specific information or content that the AI chat uses as a reference to generate responses. The user can choose to provide no context, the current page, or the current document as the context. They can also highlight specific text on the current page and choose that selection as the context. The selection of context directly influences the responses generated by Coda AI. When a specific context is provided, the AI chat uses that information to generate more relevant and accurate responses. For instance, if the context is a specific page or document, the AI chat will generate responses based on the content of that page or document. If no context is provided, the AI chat may not be able to generate as relevant or accurate responses.
Using relevant keywords in your prompts can enhance the accuracy of responses generated by Coda AI because these keywords guide the AI in understanding the context and the specific information you're seeking. The AI uses these keywords to generate responses that are closely aligned with the information you're looking for. For example, if you're asking for information about the climate in a specific region, instead of just asking "Tell me about the climate", you could ask "What is the average annual rainfall in Seattle?" or "What is the average summer temperature in Phoenix?". These prompts include relevant keywords like "rainfall", "Seattle", "summer temperature", and "Phoenix", which help the AI to generate more accurate and specific responses.
One of the limitations mentioned in the document is that Coda AI can't currently add certain Coda specific building blocks like callouts, Packs, formulas. This means that while it can generate tables and format text like headers, bold, italics, it cannot incorporate more complex elements into its output.A potential solution or workaround for this could be to manually add these elements after the AI has generated the initial content. For instance, if you need a specific formula in your document, you could use the AI to generate the rest of the content and then manually insert the formula where needed. Alternatively, the development team could work on expanding the AI's capabilities to include these features in future updates.
In Coda AI, you can retroactively edit your prompts for both AI block and AI column. For an AI block prompt, you need to right click on the block and select "Change prompt". For an AI column prompt, you need to right click on the column header and select "Edit AI". However, it is currently not possible to retroactively edit a prompt for AI assistant. This is because once the assistant has generated the text or table, and you’ve hit the "Keep" button, the system does not allow further editing of the prompt. The exact reason for this limitation is not specified in the context provided.
To reference tables, pages, columns, etc. in your AI prompt in Coda AI, follow these steps:1. Start by typing your prompt in the prompt bar. 2. When you want to reference a table, page, or column, type "@" into the prompt bar. 3. After typing "@", start typing the name of the table, page, or column you want to reference. 4. A dropdown list will appear with the objects that match the name you're typing. 5. Select the correct object from the dropdown list. 6. Continue typing your prompt as needed.Remember, you can also reference other columns in the table using the same steps when working with AI columns.

Using custom icons in Coda allows you to add more personality to your doc, whether you want to get more professional or more whimsical. Custom icons can be used in doc titles, page titles, buttons, reactions, and more. The ability to upload these custom icons in a workspace is only granted to the Doc Makers.
The two main actions discussed related to custom icons in Coda are adding custom icons and removing custom icons.

The creation date of a file is the date when the file was initially created. In this context, the file named "section_3.md" was created on November 30, 2023.The last modified date is the date when the file was last changed or updated. For the file "section_3.md", the last time it was modified or updated was also on November 30, 2023.The last accessed date is the date when the file was last opened or used, regardless of whether any changes were made to it. In this case, the "section_3.md" file was last accessed on November 30, 2023.
After clicking on the icon next to your doc title, you should follow these steps:1. Click **Custom** 2. Click **Upload** and select a file. Square images under 5MB with transparent backgrounds work best. Images can be PNG, JPEG, or GIF format. 3. Give your icon a memorable name. You’ll use this name to search for your icon in the future. 4. Click **Confirm**
A user can navigate from their doc to their workspace to add a new icon by clicking the Coda icon in the top left corner of their doc. Then, underneath the name of their workspace on the left, they should select **Icons** and click the **+New Icon**. The image specifications for the icon to be uploaded are as follows: The image should be a square and under 5MB with a transparent background. The image can be in PNG, JPEG, or GIF format.
The document 'section_31.md' provides the following step-by-step process to delete custom icons from the workspace library in Coda:1. From your document, navigate to your workspace by clicking the Coda icon in the top left corner. 2. Underneath the name of your workspace on the left, select **Icons.** 3. Find the icon you’d like to delete by searching or browsing. 4. Click the trash can icon to remove the icon from the workspace library. This will ensure no one can use this icon any longer within the workspace, but will not impact any docs or folders currently using the icon.
The docs or folders currently using the custom icon are not impacted when that icon is removed from the workspace library.

The document does not provide specific steps on how to install a Pack.
The document does not provide specific details on the procedure to request approval for installing a Pack.
To install a Pack from the Coda Gallery, follow these steps:1. Open the Coda Gallery. 2. Click on the **Packs** menu item in the left panel to browse the Packs. Alternatively, use the search box to search for the Pack you want. 3. Click on the Pack you want to install to open its listing page. 4. Click the **Add to doc** button to begin the installation. For Paid packs you haven’t yet purchased, use the **Try it** button instead to begin a trial. 5. Search and pick an existing doc you want to install the Pack into, or click the **+ New doc** button to create a new doc.After these steps, the doc will be opened and the Pack will be installed. If your Pack requires authentication, you’ll have to connect an account manually.
To install a Pack directly from within a doc using the Insert panel, follow these steps:1. Click the **Insert** button in the upper right of the doc. 2. In the side panel click on the **Packs** menu item. 3. Browse or search for the Pack you want to install. 4. Click on the Pack you want to install to open its listing page. 5. Click the **Add to doc** button to begin the installation.If the Pack is a paid one and you haven't purchased it yet, the process is slightly different. Instead of clicking the **Add to doc** button, you would use the **Try it** button to begin a trial. If the Pack requires authentication, you will be prompted to connect an account in order to complete the installation.
The steps to request approval for installing a Pack in an organization where admin has enabled Pack approvals are:1. Click the **Request access** button in the Pack’s listing page. 2. In the dialog, enter a message to accompany your request. Include any relevant details that would help the admin make a decision. 3. Click the **Send request** to send the request. You can close the dialog after this.After these steps, the organization's admin will receive a notification about the request. They may follow up for more information and will make a decision to either approve or deny the request. You will receive a notification about this decision. If approved, you will be able to install the Pack.
After you send a request for approval to install a Pack, your organization's admin will receive a notification, which includes who made the request. They may follow up with you for more information. When they make a decision, either to approve or deny, you will receive a notification with the decision. If approved, you will then be able to install the Pack.
Any of the Pack’s building blocks (formulas, actions, etc.) that are used within the doc will break once the Pack is removed. If you removed a Pack accidentally you can reinstall it to fix the errors.
Yes, here are the steps to remove a Pack from a document in Braintrust:1. Click the **Insert** button in the upper right of the doc. 2. In the side panel click on the **Packs** menu item. 3. Click on the Pack you want to remove. 4. Click on the three-dots menu in the upper right of the Pack panel and then click on **Remove Pack from doc**. 5. In the dialog click the button **Remove this Pack**.
Installing a Pack does not give it access to your account or the contents of your doc. It only makes its building blocks available to use.
According to the document "section_37.md", to determine what Packs have already been installed, you need to open the Packs panel. This can be done by clicking on "Insert", which is located in the upper right corner of your document, and then clicking on "Packs". After doing this, you will see a list of "Installed Packs".

The purpose of the importer built by the team at Coda is to allow users to move their data from Airtable to Coda. Users can import their Airtable bases into Coda with a few clicks.
The two main functionalities provided by the importer for moving data from Airtable to Coda are: importing to Coda as a new document and importing to an existing Coda document.
The purpose of the article mentioned in the document "section_4.md" is to guide customers on how to cancel their Coda subscription. This is specifically intended for customers on the Pro and Team plans.
The instructions provided in the document are intended for customers on the Pro and Team plans of Coda. If Enterprise customers want to downgrade their subscription, they should contact their account team or Coda Support.
To import an Airtable base into a new Coda doc, follow these steps:1. Start by navigating to your doc list at coda.io/docs. 2. Click on the **+ Templates** button. 3. From the menu that appears, select the **Import** option located at the bottom left. 4. Look for the **Airtable** option and click on it. 5. Next, click the **Connect Account** button to authorize the Coda application.  6. During authorization, you'll be asked to set the desired access level. You can opt to give access to a single base, a single workspace, or all workspaces. 7. After authorization, choose the base you want to import and click next. 8. The final step involves selecting your tables and views. Remember that all linked tables must be selected for the import to be successful.Please note that importing large bases may take some time.
When importing large bases from Airtable to Coda, you should consider that it may take a while for the import to fully complete. For more information on this topic, you can refer to the FAQ on load time.
The step where you authorize the coda application with the desired access level is significant because it allows you to control the level of access the coda application has to your Airtable data. You can choose to give access to a single base, single workspace, or all workspaces. This ensures that your data is protected and only the necessary information is shared with the coda application.
You should take into consideration that all linked tables must be selected during the import process to a Coda doc from Airtable.
In Coda, the concepts of Workspaces, Bases, Tables, and Views from Airtable translate in the following ways:- Workspaces in Airtable are similar to a list of Coda docs in Coda. A workspace in Coda holds these documents. - Bases in Airtable are translated to a Coda doc in Coda.  - The database capabilities of Airtable tables and views are seamlessly combined in a Coda doc, providing a flexible surface for these functionalities. - Interfaces in Airtable are replaced by Coda docs in Coda. A Coda doc is a flexible writing surface where you can mix and match tables, views, and rich content in the Canvas.The main difference is that while Airtable has separate entities for Workspaces, Bases, Tables, Views, and Interfaces, Coda combines all these functionalities into a single, flexible document (Coda doc). This allows for a more integrated and flexible user experience.
When importing data from Airtable to Coda, there are several limitations. Firstly, Airtable does not provide any information on the specific formulas used in formula or rollup fields, and there is also no information provided with regards to grouping. However, these limitations can be addressed in Coda as it supports formulas and grouping. These columns will just need to be updated post import.Secondly, automations are not exported from Airtable’s API. To address this, Coda has Automations that can be quickly created by using the /automations command.Lastly, Airtable doesn’t provide a way to export interfaces, so these cannot be directly imported into Coda docs. However, Coda is an all-in-one doc, allowing you to present information in any way you see fit. You can mix and match tables, views, and rich content, right in the Canvas.In terms of translating Airtable concepts to Coda, Airtable's Workspaces, Bases, Tables and Views have similar concepts in Coda. A workspace in Coda holds a list of Coda docs, Airtable Bases translate to a Coda doc, and interfaces in Airtable are replaced by Coda docs. It's also worth noting that the import process may take some time due to rate limiting on the Airtable API, which limits the number of calls that can be made per second.

A unique feature of Packs is their custom column formats. These columns allow you to get rich information related to the specific integration, whether it be Spotify, Salesforce, or GMail. For example, the Google Calendar Pack includes the "Event" column format. This format allows you to paste a simple URL of a Google Calendar event into your Coda table. It then returns detailed information about the event, including date, start time, attendees, and more. This information can even be turned into separate columns.
Based on the context information provided, the three main topics that you would expect to learn about in the article are:1. "Add Pack columns": This topic would likely cover how to add custom column formats, or "Packs", to your Coda table. It may provide step-by-step instructions or tips for adding these columns, which are a feature of Packs that allow you to get rich information related to specific integrations like Spotify, Salesforce, or GMail.2. "Get rich data from links": This section would likely explain how to use these custom column formats to extract detailed information from simple URLs. For example, the context mentions that the Google Calendar Pack's "Event" column format allows you to paste a URL of a GCal event into your Coda table and get detailed information about the event.3. "FAQs": This section would likely address common questions or issues that users might have when using Pack column formats. This could include troubleshooting tips, additional resources, or more detailed explanations of certain features.
To add a Pack column to a table in your doc as described in 'section_45.md', you need to follow these steps:1. Ensure that the Pack is installed in your doc. This is a prerequisite for the process. 2. Create a new column in your table by clicking the plus icon in the upper right corner of your table. 3. From the column type options, search for the Pack name. 4. You should then see a list of the possible columns for that Pack. 5. Click on an option to add it to your table.After you've added a Pack column to your table, you can typically learn more about how the column is meant to work by right clicking on the column header, then selecting the column options.
You can learn more about the functionality of a newly added Pack column in your table by right clicking on the column header and then selecting the column options.
A URL column in Packs, a feature in Coda, allows users to paste URLs from an external tool directly into a Coda table to view detailed information from that URL. The URL automatically converts into an object that contains all the associated information. For instance, if you use the Jira Issues column type, you can paste the URL of a Jira Issue into the column of your Coda table. The URL will then convert to an object that contains all the information related to that issue.Once a URL column format is added, you can start pasting URLs into the column. You can then choose to add any of the fields as columns. To do this, hover over the object in the initial URL column. A scrollable pop-up will appear displaying all the data contained in that object. Next to each field, there is an "Add column" button. By clicking this button, the column will be added to your table. The information in that column is auto-populated based on the URL. This way, you can gather and organize detailed information from an external tool like Jira, directly in your Coda table.
To add new fields as columns from a URL column in a Coda table, you first need to add a URL column format. Once this is done, you can start pasting URLs into the column. After pasting the URL, you can choose to add any of the fields as columns. To do this, hover over the object in the initial URL column. A scrollable pop-up should appear displaying all the data contained in that object. Next to each field, there is an "Add column" button. When you click this button, the column will be added to your table. The information in that new column is automatically populated based on the URL.
Pack sync tables and Pack URL columns in Coda serve different purposes. Pack sync tables are designed to automatically bring in sets of data from a third-party tool based on the filter criteria you set for the sync. For example, you might set up a sync table to pull in all data from a certain project in a project management tool, or all emails from a certain sender in an email tool. Coda will search the available data and pull in any and all rows that match the criteria of your sync settings.On the other hand, Pack URL columns allow you to manually curate whichever pieces of data you want to include in your table. For instance, you might use a Pack URL column to include specific songs from Spotify in a table, or specific articles from a news website. You paste the URL of the specific piece of data into the column, and Coda will pull in the relevant data from that URL.So, the main difference is that Pack sync tables are for automatic, criteria-based data import, while Pack URL columns are for manual, specific data import.
If you pasted a link into a Pack column format and nothing happened, there are several steps you can take to troubleshoot. First, you should check that your Pack is installed and your connection is working. You can do this by clicking the Insert icon located in the upper right corner of the document, then searching for the Pack you're troubleshooting.Next, you need to ensure that the link you're pasting matches the format of the column. For instance, if you're using the Spotify Pack, it offers three column formats: Album, Track, and Playlist. The Album column will only work with links to albums, the Track column will only work with links to tracks, and so on. The format of the link is crucial because links often contain a hint as to the format of their referenced data in the URL. For example, the link 'open.spotify.com/album/' refers to an album and should be pasted into a column of format Album. So, the format of the column and the link is very important in this context as it determines whether the pasted link will work or not. If the formats do not match, the link will not work as expected.
